posts.cooked:
I’m attempting to update our code from last season’s bot to the most recent version of YAGSL and am running into issues.  Due to school networking restrictions, I need to use the offline method for updating.  Reading the documentation, I should be copying the swervelib directory from the YAGSL example code into the src/main/java directory of my project.  The issues Im running into:

I don’t see a swervelib directory in the example code linked from the documentation…at least not in src/main/java, and I couldn’t locate it elsewhere.

I don’t see a swervelib directory in the example code linked from the documentation…at least not in src/main/java, and I couldn’t locate it elsewhere.

I also don’t have a src/main/java/swervelib directory in my current codebase.  Attempting an update, I expected to be overwriting an existing directory?

I also don’t have a src/main/java/swervelib directory in my current codebase.  Attempting an update, I expected to be overwriting an existing directory?

I suspect I’m missing something simple, but right now, the only place I see swervelib in my code is in a .jar file in the Java Projects folder in Visual Studio, and I can’t seem to edit anything there.

I won’t be able to play with this until Tuesday, but am hoping to gather a list of solutions to explore before then, so any suggestions are very much appreciated!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Tagging the right person @nstrike …

I’m sure he can help.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: If you downloaded from the main branch, there won’t be a swervelib directory, it will use the vendor library. Switch to the dev branch in GitHub to get the version with swervelib. You will still need to be able to download other vendor libraries, though, either with online or offline install.

Thanks!  Will using the directory instead of the vendor library mess with our existing code…requiring updates elsewhere?

The new version should work with the other vendor libraries that are already loaded, right?

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
I can’t think of any reason the directory would clash. Let me put it this way, I’ve switched my code base back and forth between vendor and directory on the fly because of bug fixes I was making to YAGSL and never missed a beat.

As long as the other library versions match well enough, I don’t think just having the code there would clash. A missing API or changed parameter might become immediately obvious, but if there were some bug fix dependency it might not. So, you may need to just give it a try. As long as you’re using relatively recent libraries, that should be ok. You should probably update in build season before you get locked into a set of libraries, if being able to update regularly is an issue.
Awesome!  I’ll give this a try.  Thanks!
This did the trick.  Thank you for the help!
